verses.text: I speak the truth in Christ— I am not lying, my conscience confirms it in the Holy Spirit—
verses.comment: Paul stresses his sincerity before God, showing deep dependence on the Holy Spirit for testimony. This affirms the work of the Spirit in bearing witness to truth within the believer, a pointed reference to the importance of Spirit-guided conscience.

verses.text: I have great sorrow and continuous anguish in my heart.
verses.comment: Paul’s personal grief for Israel reflects the longing for the salvation of all. His anguish models intercessory prayer for others’ salvation, connected to Christ’s compassion for Jerusalem (Luke 19:41).

verses.text: For I could wish that I myself were accursed and cut off from Christ for the sake of my brothers, my kinsmen according to the flesh.
verses.comment: Paul’s willingness to be cut off resembles Moses’ intercession for Israel. This sacrificial love reflects Christ’s own self-giving and the high value placed on unity among God’s people.

verses.text: They are Israelites; theirs is the adoption as sons, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the Law, the worship, and the promises.
verses.comment: Paul summarizes Israel’s privileges—adoption, glory, covenants—foundational concepts fulfilled in Christ and extended through the Church. The spiritual inheritance given here anticipates God’s plan that embraces Gentiles.

verses.text: Theirs are the patriarchs, and from them, according to the flesh, came the Messiah, who is God over all, blessed forever. Amen.
verses.comment: Paul affirms that the Messiah came from Israel ‘according to the flesh’ and asserts His divinity. This high view of Christ matches the confession in John 20:28: ‘My Lord and my God.’

verses.text: But it is not as though God’s word has failed. For not all who are descended from Israel are Israel.
verses.comment: Paul clarifies that being a true Israelite is not a matter of physical descent but spiritual calling. The Church inherits this identity in Christ, signifying spiritual Israel (Gal. 6:16).

verses.text: Nor are they all Abraham’s children because they are his descendants, but ‘Through Isaac your descendants shall be named.’
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes the children of promise from mere physical offspring. God’s election operates according to His divine plan. This sets up the teaching on spiritual sonship by faith.

verses.text: That is, it is not the children of the flesh who are children of God, but the children of the promise are regarded as descendants.
verses.comment: Here, Paul emphasizes spiritual adoption in God’s covenant, fulfilled by faith and sacramental grace, which transcends natural birth distinctions.

verses.text: For this was the promise: ‘At the appointed time I will come, and Sarah will have a son.’
verses.comment: Paul shows how God’s promise to Abraham is fulfilled by His initiative, not human effort, pointing to the supernatural work in salvation and Christ’s birth.

verses.text: Not only that, but also when Rebekah had conceived children by one man, our father Isaac—
verses.comment: Paul continues the theme of election with Rebekah’s children, setting the stage for divine choice based on God’s purpose rather than human merit.

verses.text: Though they had not yet been born or done anything good or bad—in order that God’s purpose in election might stand, not because of works but because of Him who calls—
verses.comment: God’s sovereign election is independent of human actions, exemplifying grace. The mystery of divine predestination remains a source of awe, leading to trust in God’s wisdom.

verses.text: She was told, ‘The older will serve the younger.’
verses.comment: God reverses human expectations, demonstrating His freedom in choosing His instruments. This pattern reflects the unexpected ways He works in salvation history, culminating in Christ.

verses.text: As it is written, ‘Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.’
verses.comment: God’s preference for Jacob over Esau highlights His sovereignty. ‘Hated’ here is a Semitic expression for preference, not emotional hostility.

verses.text: What shall we say then? Is there injustice with God? By no means!
verses.comment: Paul defends God’s fairness—His justice is perfect regardless of human perception. The theme calls for humility before divine mystery.

verses.text: For He says to Moses, ‘I will show mercy to whom I show mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.’
verses.comment: God’s mercy is His sovereign gift, not subject to human demand. Paul’s citation of Exodus roots election in the divine prerogative witnessed throughout biblical history.

verses.text: So then, it does not depend on human will or effort, but on God who shows mercy.
verses.comment: Salvation is initiated by God’s grace. The humility required here opens the heart to trust in both faith and works as responses to God’s mercy, not human achievement alone.

verses.text: For the Scripture says to Pharaoh, ‘I raised you up for this very purpose, that I might show My power in you, and that My Name might be proclaimed in all the earth.’
verses.comment: God uses even those opposed to Him for His glory and the spread of His Name. The narrative prefigures the ultimate triumph in Christ’s resurrection and worldwide proclamation.

verses.text: Therefore, He has mercy on whom He wishes, and He hardens whom He wishes.
verses.comment: The tension between mercy and hardening invites deeper trust in God’s wisdom. This mystery calls us to prayerful reflection and humility before divine sovereignty.

verses.text: You will say to me, ‘Then why does He still find fault? For who can resist His will?’
verses.comment: Paul voices a common objection about human responsibility. The relationship between grace and free will is a perennial debate, with deeper layers pointing to mystery.

verses.text: But who are you, O man, to answer back to God? Will what is formed say to the one who formed it, ‘Why did you make me like this?’
verses.comment: Paul invokes imagery of the potter and clay, emphasizing God’s absolute authority as Creator. This metaphor calls believers to surrender and acceptance of God’s purpose.

verses.text: Does not the potter have the right over the clay, to make from the same lump one vessel for honorable use and another for common use?
verses.comment: Paul continues potter imagery, framing God’s sovereignty while implying a sanctifying call for those chosen for ‘honorable use.’ The Church stands as a vessel set apart by God’s election.

verses.text: What if God, desiring to show His wrath and make His power known, endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction?
verses.comment: God’s patience with the unrighteous displays His mercy and justice. Even judgment serves the revelation of God’s attributes and patience in salvation history.

verses.text: And what if He did so to make known the riches of His glory on vessels of mercy, which He prepared beforehand for glory—
verses.comment: God prepares believers for glory. This highlights the doctrine of justification and sanctification, built upon God’s initiative and the fullness of sacramental grace.

verses.text: Even us, whom He called, not only from the Jews but also from the Gentiles?
verses.comment: Paul affirms God’s inclusive call. The Church embodies this unity of Israel and Gentiles, fulfilling prophecy and God’s eternal plan.

verses.text: As He says in Hosea, ‘I will call those who were not My people, ‘My people,’ and her who was not beloved, ‘Beloved.’’
verses.comment: Paul cites Hosea to show that Gentiles are included in God’s family. The Church fulfills this promise of love and belonging, a core reality of Christian identity.

verses.text: And, ‘In the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not My people,’ there they will be called sons of the living God.’
verses.comment: Through Christ, former outsiders become God’s children. The Church’s sacramental life lays out this adoption, expanding God’s covenant family to all nations.

verses.text: Isaiah cries out concerning Israel: ‘Though the number of the sons of Israel be as the sand of the sea, only a remnant will be saved.’
verses.comment: Paul highlights a remnant theology—God’s promise persists but not all are saved by birthright alone. A faithful remnant embraces both the blessings and responsibilities of grace.

verses.text: For the Lord will carry out His sentence on the earth swiftly and decisively.
verses.comment: God’s action is swift and sovereign. Paul reiterates God’s faithfulness; Christ’s coming brings rapid fulfillment of all prophecy.

verses.text: And just as Isaiah said before: ‘If the Lord of hosts had not left us descendants, we would have become like Sodom, and been made like Gomorrah.’
verses.comment: God’s preservation of a faithful remnant is an act of mercy. Even amid judgment, His promise endures for those united to Him through faith and sacramental grace.

verses.text: What shall we say then? That Gentiles, though they did not pursue righteousness, have attained righteousness—by faith;
verses.comment: Paul declares righteousness comes by faith, not merely by works. This teaching is the heart of justification, completed in sacramental union with Christ.

verses.text: but Israel, pursuing a law of righteousness, did not attain it.
verses.comment: Israel’s striving by law without faith was insufficient. Paul’s argument points to the necessity of grace as the basis for righteousness, anticipated in the prophets.

verses.text: Why? Because they did not pursue it by faith, but as if it were by works. They stumbled over the ‘stumbling stone,’
verses.comment: Paul connects faith, works, and Christ as the ‘stumbling stone.’ Many missed righteousness by rejecting faith in Jesus, as prophesied in the Old Testament.

verses.text: as it is written: ‘See, I lay in Zion a stone that causes people to stumble and a rock that makes them fall, and whoever believes in Him will not be put to shame.’
verses.comment: Christ is the prophesied cornerstone. Faith in Him secures our place in God’s house; this verse affirms the importance of both personal trust and abiding in the visible, sacramental community founded by Christ Himself.
